Post-doctoral fellowships are now
an essential part of the new scholarship system of the Johns Hopkins
University, as formally announced by
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, President of the
University, in his Commemoration
Day Address. In the old system the
available funds were only in certain
cases allotted to post-graduate fellows, whereas the new allocation of
finances makes definite provision for
a number of fellowships of this nature, some of which are to yield $1,500 yer year.
The new policy is the result of a
survey of the existing scholarship
system at the University by a scholarship committee, of which Dr. W.
Stull Holt is the head. The committee was organized for the purpose cf
insuring the effective use of the existing resources and to make plans
for a permanent policy which the
Hopkins will follow in the future.
The most significant recommendations of the committee are embodied
in two reports, the first of which includes the post-doctoral plan. Dr.
Bowman, in his address, stated: "In
pledge of faith in friends whose support we seek, the University has itself acted in behalf of graduate student encouragement and takes a new
step forward by transferring a group
of graduate fellowships to the advanced post-doctoral level. Reserved
for students who have met, or all but
met, the requirements of a doctor's
degree and who have 'also demonstarted originality of a high order,
these fellowships are designed to en-

able a man to avoid the danger of
having his ability and scholarship
destroyed by a heavy teaching schedule. The years of his most imaginative work are thus reserved for sheer
intellectual growth and the development of a problem which he could not
advance sufficiently far while meeting the technical requirements for a
degree. If adequate support for the
enlargement of the plan is forthcoming there is no reason why this step
should not prove as important for
higher education as that which was
taken in 1876, when the University
was founded on the principle of highest quality in graduate study appropriately called the heart of true university work. These fellowships are
open to men and women from other
American institutions, as well as the
Hopkins, and we hope that in a few
years we can announce participation
by foreign students."
Ten Fellowships Urged
The scholarship committee which
made the survey recommended that
the ten fellowships heretofore available to students of any subject be
increased and confined exclusively to
the young men who have recently received the degree of Doctor of Philosophy. Their plan also called for
ten additional fellowships of this nature to yield $1500 per year to be
created. It was pointed out that if
the University created funds available for publishing scholarly works
of these post-doctoral fellows, it
would greatly enhance the attractive
powers of the fellowships.

three days, April 16, 17, 18.

spoke to the group, suggesting the
holding of a dance to top off the "Hell
Week" struggle. A vote was taken,
and a distinct majority refused to
support such an affair. Disregarding
this vote, Freshman President Bob
Ward spoke to the group and succeeded in swinging the vote into his
favor. As one Hopkins politician described it:
"It was one of the cleverest pieces

ever seen."

It is evident that those men who
"won't put up any money" until liberal expression on the campus is
stopped understand the attitude of
the scholar as poorly as perpetrators
of teachers' oath bills. Dr. Bowman,
in his Commemoration Day address,
emphasized the necessity of this attitude when he said that freedom to
"think, to discover, and to report is
more important than either government or society itself."
It was this liberal character—the
kind that refused to accept anything
as the truth merely because somebody in the past had said it was, and
somebody ,in the present mightn't
like it nto to be so—that blessed the
world with the works of men like
Vesalius, Pare, and Paracelsus in
medicine; like Keppler, Galileo, and
Newton in physics, and so on in every branch of learning. When one
considers it, it seems to be, to put it
kindly, silly for these offended men
of wealth to attempt to buy out the
free expressions of our modern scholars, backed, as they are, by these
centuries of civilization's progress
through the medium of unfettered
thought.

COLD FACTS:
All those students who failed to
hear President Bowman speak Saturday should by all means get a copy
of his speech and read it. Their eyes
would be opened to the reason for
their four-year visit to the Johns
Hopkins, they would learn that they
are supposed to be a selected group
destined to leave something more

found there, they would be thoroughly imbued with the idea of the search
for truth, they would not lose themselves in their books and become unaware of the outside world, and they
would realize that each one of them

Warner Baxter appears in "The
Prisoner of Shark Island", now playing at the New Theater. This 20th
Century-Fox production
tells the
story of Dr. Samuel Alexander
Mudd, played by Mr. Baxter, who
has for a long time been considered
one of the conspirators in the death
of President Abraham Lincoln, because he treated the broken leg of
John Wilkes Booth.
For his deed, Dr. Mudd is arrested and sentenced to Shark Island,
a prison located in the Caribbean.
There, Mudd is cruelly maltreatetl
and finally thrown into solitary confinement where he remains until a
yellow fever epidemic on the island
reaches such high proportions that
the medical officer is unable to cope
with it. Then Mudd is called into
action. Naturally, he proves to be
the big hero when he gets the epidemic under control, wins the friendship of the men on the island, and
his own freedom.

Post-doctoral fellowships are now
an essential part of the new scholarship system of the Johns Hopkins
University, as formally announced by
Dr. Isaiah Bowman, President of the
University, in his Commemoration
Day Address. In the old system the
available funds were only in certain
cases allotted to post-graduate fellows, whereas the new allocation of
finances makes definite provision for
a number of fellowships of this nature, some of which are to yield $1,500 yer year.
The new policy is the result of a
survey of the existing scholarship
system at the University by a scholarship committee, of which Dr. W.
Stull Holt is the head. The committee was organized for the purpose cf
insuring the effective use of the existing resources and to make plans
for a permanent policy which the
Hopkins will follow in the future.
The most significant recommendations of the committee are embodied
in two reports, the first of which includes the post-doctoral plan. Dr.
Bowman, in his address, stated: "In
pledge of faith in friends whose support we seek, the University has itself acted in behalf of graduate student encouragement and takes a new
step forward by transferring a group
of graduate fellowships to the advanced post-doctoral level. Reserved
for students who have met, or all but
met, the requirements of a doctor's
degree and who have 'also demonstarted originality of a high order,
these fellowships are designed to en-

able a man to avoid the danger of
having his ability and scholarship
destroyed by a heavy teaching schedule. The years of his most imaginative work are thus reserved for sheer
intellectual growth and the development of a problem which he could not
advance sufficiently far while meeting the technical requirements for a
degree. If adequate support for the
enlargement of the plan is forthcoming there is no reason why this step

higher education as that which was
taken in 1876, when the University

American institutions, as well as the
Hopkins, and we hope that in a few
years we can announce participation
by foreign students."

made the survey recommended that
the ten fellowships heretofore available to students of any subject be
increased and confined exclusively to
the young men who have recently received the degree of Doctor of Philosophy. Their plan also called for
ten additional fellowships of this nature to yield $1500 per year to be
created. It was pointed out that if
the University created funds available for publishing scholarly works
of these post-doctoral fellows, it
would greatly enhance the attractive
powers of the fellowships.
